channel.title: [iOS] 4.2.1 Firmware Update
channel.description:
http://www.apple.com/ios/ [img]http://images.apple.com/ios/images/fmip20101116.jpg[/img]
Find My iPhone, iPad, or iPod touch — the MobileMe feature that helps you locate your missing device and protect its data — is now free on any iPhone 4, iPad, or fourth-generation iPod touch running iOS 4.2 Once you set it up, you can find your lost device on a map, display a message on its screen, remotely set a passcode lock, and initiate a remote wipe to delete your data. And if you eventually find your iPhone, iPad, or iPod touch, you can restore everything from your last backup.
Quite cool, if your phone gets stolen you can send them messages, locate the phone, wipe data etc. Does android have a similar feature?

item.title: [iOS] 4.2.1 Firmware Update
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:
@Saphire1 wrote:

Android has had this feature since 1.6, although android are only at 2.2 at the moment it has been a long time. The iphone version of this app is a lot more stable than androids, it is also user friendly and has more features.

Read full topic

item.title: [iOS] 4.2.1 Firmware Update
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Thug-life, post:23, topic:370139”]Go on, do Stephen Fry’s.

Else, fuck up. You’re going way beyond what is directly relevant to the actual point of the service with examples that don’t just apply to this.[/quote]

I might have to clarify my post. I myself do not give a fuck about the location of you or Stephen Fry. My point is that when someone, for instance a witness in a big trial or some cocksucker who happens to be a target for some (criminal-) organization, happily walks around with his iPenis in his pants, he can be tracked down easily.

item.title: [iOS] 4.2.1 Firmware Update
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:14, topic:370139”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=466258.msg3412226#msg3412226 date=1290788877]
What prevents me from finding out where you are?
[/quote]
A logon form[/quote]

And what prevents me from logging in? Sure, you have a password. But if I was genuinely interested in your location, and had a certain goal, I’d have the ability to figure out your password. Given the fact that a lot of iWhatever users are pretty active on social media, I’d be able to profile you and find out your password. For someone that has a good reason to find out where you are, it’s not that hard.

Read full topic

item.title: [iOS] 4.2.1 Firmware Update
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Well, wiping the phone after 10 wrong tries would take hours. Because it locks your phone for longer increments of time after certain amount (3, 5, 7 etc). Besides, you can turn that little option off, they can get the passcode wrong for as long as they want and it’ll do nothing.

And yeah, if you plug the phone into a computer it hasn’t been connected to before, or an iTunes copy it hasn’t been synced with the phone before - it’ll ask you to input the passcode before you can do anything.

Again, it isn’t going to be prevent people from stealing your phone, but it gives you a chance in getting it back, and same if you loose it. If it is lost forever, you can send the remote wipe command and it’ll execute it as soon as it gets a connection.

Read full topic

item.title: [iOS] 4.2.1 Firmware Update
item.dc:creator: @Uriko Uriko
item.description:
@Uriko wrote:

[quote=“Thug-life, post:12, topic:370139”]You’d have to get through the pass code first, and most people have it set to wipe the phone on 10 false tries.

Of course, there are ways to stop this happening, but most thieves aren’t going to do that.[/quote]Woah, I definitely wouldn’t use that option. I have retarded friends. Oh, and Unhandled, if there’s no pass code you could just immediately turn 3G connectivity off I’m assuming and you’re good to go.

Read full topic
